feed.title: NewsTracker: ebola
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: 'Progress' in Ebola fight, but 'substantial risks' remain: WHO
entry.summary: Such measures not only interfere with international travel and impact local economies, but also hamper Ebola response and recovery efforts because they make it more difficult for aid workers to move in and out of the affected countries, Aylward said.

entry.title: Liberia watchdog says some Ebola funds unaccounted for
entry.summary: The General Auditing Commission (GAC) report covering the period from August to October 2014 analysed more than $13 million spent by the National Ebola Trust Fund (NETF).

entry.title: Two experimental Ebola vaccines pass safety test in African trial
entry.summary: "Now we must move forward to adapt and expand the study so that ultimately we can determine whether these experimental vaccines can protect against Ebola virus disease and therefore be used in future Ebola outbreaks."

entry.title: Americans evacuated after possible Ebola contact
entry.summary:
A health care worker prepares a colleague's protective gear at an Ebola virus clinic operated by the International Medical Corps in Makeni, Sierra Leone.

Another aid worker, who was showing signs of illness, arrived in the US on Friday evening, hours after a colleague with Ebola was flown from Sierra Leone to the clinical centre of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland.

entry.title: Scientists to share real-time genetic data on deadly MERS, Ebola
entry.summary: The gene sequences, already available for MERS cases and soon to come in the case of Ebola, will be posted on the website virological.org for anyone to see, access and use.

entry.title: Aust to close Ebola treatment centre
entry.summary: Australia will close its Ebola treatment centre in Sierra Leone by the end of April, returning $7.5 million to an emergency humanitarian fund.

entry.title: Soccer idols Zidane and Ronaldo team up in U.N. Ebola fundraiser
entry.summary: "We are delighted to play a part in helping people, communities and countries get back on their feet after the damage that Ebola has caused," Ronaldo said in a statement.

entry.title: WHO admits serious failings over handling of Ebola, promises reform
entry.summary: Some critics have said that its reluctance to declare the outbreak an emergency were major factors in allowing the epidemic to balloon into the worst Ebola crisis on record, with more than 25,000 cases and 10,000 deaths.

entry.title: WHO admits failings during Ebola crisis
entry.summary: The statement listed eight lessons learned, including areas where the WHO's response to Ebola could have been better, such as information sharing and communication.

entry.title: WHO admits failings during Ebola crisis
entry.summary:
The World Health Organization has admitted several failings during the Ebola crisis.

The World Health Organization has admitted serious failings in its handling of the Ebola crisis and pledged reforms to enable it to do better next time, its leadership said in a statement seen by Reuters on Sunday.

entry.title: Soldier death feared Ebola-related blamed on synthetic pot
entry.summary: Fort Hood officials say Sneed had returned the previous week from Liberia, where he helped construct an Ebola treatment camp but wasn't exposed to patients.

entry.title: Soldier death feared Ebola-related blamed on synthetic pot
entry.summary: KILLEEN, Texas (AP) - An autopsy has concluded that synthetic marijuana was to blame for the death of a Fort Hood soldier shortly after his return from deployment to an Ebola hot zone in West Africa.

entry.title: Guinea finds nine new Ebola cases near border with Sierra Leone
entry.summary:
Guinean authorities have confirmed at least nine new cases of Ebola in the southwest region of Forecariah near the border with Sierra Leone, the area hardest hit by the year-old outbreak, a senior health official said on Thursday.

Authorities launched a four day, door-to-door campaign in Forecariah on April 12 to improve community participation in reporting suspected cases and as part of an emergency 45-day drive to tackle Ebola in the west of the country.

entry.title: Guinea finds nine new Ebola cases near border with Sierra Leone
entry.summary: Sakoba Keita, national coordinator for the fight against Ebola in the West African country, said authorities had also detected 10 suspicious deaths in the community but only one of these had been confirmed as Ebola.

entry.title: Obama says Ebola-fighting goal is to prevent any new cases
entry.summary: On Capitol Hill, top government health officials echoed the president's message, saying that while recent efforts fighting Ebola have been encouraging, the threat is far from over,.

entry.title: Obama says Ebola-fighting goal is to prevent any new cases
entry.summary: "This virus is unpredictable, we have to be vigilant and the international community has to be fully engaged in a partnership with these three countries until there are no cases of Ebola in these countries."

entry.title: Obama to meet West African presidents on Wednesday to discuss Ebola
Sierra Leone schools reopen after long closure due to Ebola
entry.summary:
"The scepticism is based on fear of Ebola because people are not very confident of sending their children if schools are not well prepared," he said.

At the Prince of Wales secondary school in the west of the city, hundreds of pupils showed up in a compound that medical charity Medicins Sans Frontieres used as an Ebola care centre just a few weeks previously.

In all, more than 9,000 children were orphaned by Ebola in Sierra Leone, some of whom survived the disease themselves.

entry.title: Sierra Leone schools re-open after Ebola closed for 9 months
entry.summary:
More than 8,000 schools are to reopen for about 1.8 million students and the government and U.N. children's agency promise to check temperatures regularly and will promote hand washing to discourage the spread of Ebola in the schools.

Since October 2014, UNICEF has supported the government in running daily emergency radio education programs to allow children to continue learning at home during the Ebola crisis.

entry.title: Sierra Leone schools re-open after Ebola closed for 9 months
entry.summary: The Ebola crisis is estimated to have infected more than 25,500 people and killed 10,587.

entry.title: Schools re-open in Sierra Leone after Ebola outbreak forced closures for 9 months
entry.summary:
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone - Children in Sierra Leone are returning to schools after the Ebola outbreak forced closures about nine months ago.

UNICEF Sierra Leone says it has facilitated the training of 9,000 teachers in Ebola prevention, safety guidelines and psycho-social support.

entry.title: Nicaragua asks US to remove embassy worker over Ebola worry
entry.summary: The U.S. embassy in Managua said in a statement that the employee was in Liberia, but denied there had been any contact with Ebola patients.

entry.title: Nicaragua Asks US to Remove Embassy Worker Over Ebola Worry
entry.summary: Nicaragua has asked the United States to remove an embassy worker who was in Liberia because it fears the person may have been exposed to the Ebola virus that has devastated several West African countries.

entry.title: Empty Ebola Clinics in Liberia Are Seen as Misstep in U.S. Relief Effort
entry.summary:
Nine centers have never had a single Ebola patient.

"My task was to convince the international organizations, 'You don't need any more E.T.U.s,' " said Dr. Hans Rosling, a Swedish public health expert who advised Liberia's health ministry, referring to Ebola treatment units.

entry.title: Risk of Ebola spreading to other countries appears to be falling: WHO
entry.summary: Falling Ebola cases make completing big clinical trials on experimental vaccines a challenge, with the best hope resting on a study in Guinea, Aylward said.

entry.title: Woman returns negative Ebola test
entry.summary: The health worker began showing possible symptoms of the virus on Friday afternoon, shortly after arriving back in Australia from an Ebola treatment centre in Liberia.

entry.title: Woman returns negative Ebola test
entry.summary: A woman in isolation at a Canberra hospital has tested negative to the first of two Ebola tests.

entry.title: Ebola: The Fight To Reach Zero And The Road To Recovery
entry.summary: To learn more about the NGO response and the continued efforts, listen to my segment on Fighting Ebola, an online audio series hosted by the U.S. Department of State.

entry.title: Risk of Ebola spreading to other countries appears to be falling: WHO
entry.summary: The WHO's Emergency Committee, comprising independent experts who conferred on Thursday, was "absolutely firm" in maintaining that view, said Dr. Bruce Aylward, WHO Special Representative for the Ebola Response.

entry.title: Risk of Ebola spreading to other countries appears to lessen: WHO
entry.summary: GENEVA (Reuters) - West Africa's Ebola epidemic still poses a threat to other countries, but the risk of it spreading internationally appears to be diminishing, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday.

entry.title: FDA modifies partial clinical hold on Tekmira Ebola study
entry.summary: The company's application to study the treatment, TKM-Ebola, remains on partial clinical hold for doses above 0.24 mg/kg per day, Tekmira said on Friday.

entry.title: Risk of Ebola spreading to other countries seen as less - WHO
entry.summary: The experts, who form WHO's Emergency Committee on Ebola, also made a strong recommendation that all countries "avoid any unnecessary interference with international trade and transport" beyond temporary restrictions already in place, Aylward said.

entry.title: UN: Ebola still global emergency despite big drop in cases
entry.summary: Dr. Bruce Aylward, who is leading WHO's Ebola response, said the decline appeared to be real, rather than just "a pothole on the bumpy road to get to zero cases."

entry.title: UN: Ebola still global emergency despite big drop in cases
entry.summary:
LONDON (AP) " The World Health Organization says the year-long Ebola outbreak in West Africa still qualifies as an international emergency even though the number of cases has plummeted.

During a press briefing in Geneva on Friday, Aylward said WHO's Ebola emergency committee believes the risk of the virus spreading globally appears to be dropping even though officials still don't know where the virus is spreading in most cases in Guinea and Sierra Leone.

He said the designation of Ebola as a global emergency is also necessary to speed up paperwork for the ongoing experimental drug and vaccine trials in West Africa.

entry.title: Woman isolated for possible Ebola
entry.summary: Health officials say it's most unlikely she has Ebola and her symptoms - a fever and stomach upset - are consistent with many other conditions.

entry.title: Woman isolated for possible Ebola
entry.summary:
The unnamed woman returned to Australia on April 5 after working in an Ebola treatment centre in Liberia.

"Ebola is not a particularly transmissible infection under normal circumstances. It's transmitted by direct contact with bodily fluids so we are confident there is no risk to the wider community," he said.

entry.title: Man in hospital for possible Ebola
entry.summary:
A man is being treated at Canberra hospital after displaying symptoms which could be the deadly Ebola disease.

ACT Health Acting Chief Health Officer Dr Andrew Pengilley said he worked as a medical professional in Liberia where there had been a large number of Ebola cases.

entry.title: American with Ebola released from U.S. hospital-aid group, NIH
entry.summary: According to the group, their colleague was declared Ebola-free after two consecutive negative tests, and has been declared no longer contagious and able to return home.

entry.title: American with Ebola released from U.S. hospital, aid group says
entry.summary: Sheila Davis, chief of Ebola response for Boston-based Partners In Health, said the group is "heartened by the news that our colleague is heading home, free of Ebola, and making his way toward a full recovery."

entry.title: Only 30 new cases of Ebola reported last week: WHO
entry.summary:
The Ebola epidemic, which began in December 2013, has claimed 10,572 lives among 25,515 known cases, according to the United Nations health agency.

Each country would retain a core capacity of high-quality Ebola treatment centers, strategically located to ensure complete geographic coverage, with additional rapid-response capacity held in reserve.

entry.title: 30 new Ebola cases, lowest weekly figure in nearly a year, says WHO
Obama discusses Ebola outbreak in West Africa with advisers
Obama discusses Ebola outbreak in West Africa with advisers
entry.summary: WASHINGTON (AP) - President Barack Obama has received a briefing about the Ebola outbreak in West Africa and has made clear to aides the urgency of reducing the number of cases to zero.

entry.title: Ebola-hit Sierra Leone's police arrests 13 for unsafe burial
entry.summary: Police in Ebola-hit Sierre Leone raided a funeral today and arrested 13 people suspected of organising an unsafe burial, risking spreading the disease, officers said.

entry.title: Dallas hospital seeks dismissal of nurse's suit over Ebola
entry.summary: A hospital operator denied allegations of poor training and improper preparation in seeking dismissal of a lawsuit by a nurse who contracted Ebola while caring for the first U.S. patient to succumb to the deadly disease.

entry.title: Dallas hospital seeks dismissal of nurse's suit over Ebola
entry.summary: "Nina Pham has gone through the unprecedented challenge of being the first nurse to whom the Ebola virus was transmitted while caring for a patient with Ebola in the U.S.," the statement said.

entry.title: Patient in Barrie, Ont., isolated for possible Ebola infection
entry.summary: Although the risk is considered low-risk the patient will be tested to rule out Ebola at the designated centre.

entry.title: Sierra Leone's Kailahun district records first Ebola case in months
entry.summary: Nearly 3,800 people have died of Ebola in Sierra Leone but numbers of weekly cases are falling as steps to control the disease take hold.

entry.title: Sierra Leone's Kailahun district records first Ebola case in months
entry.summary: A 9-month-old boy tested positive for Ebola after dying in Kailahun, the district on Guinea's border that recorded Sierra Leone's first Ebola case last May and was for months the epicenter of the crisis.

entry.title: Eastern Sierra Leone records first Ebola case in months
entry.summary: FREETOWN, April 4 (Reuters) - Sierra Leone's eastern district of Kailahun, once a hotbed of Ebola, has recorded its first case in nearly four months, threatening progress made to stamp out the disease, officials said on Saturday.

entry.title: NSW health worker undergoes Ebola testing
Liberia, Sierra Leone gain in Ebola crisis; Guinea struggles
entry.summary: That's primarily because Ebola has yet to explode in a major Guinean city, as it did in the capitals of Sierra Leone and Liberia, said Dr. Dan Jernigan of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

entry.title: Liberia, Sierra Leone gain in Ebola crisis; Guinea struggles
entry.summary: The West African nations of Sierra Leone and Liberia both appear to be on a steady path to ending the epidemic - the wild card is Guinea, where Ebola hasn't burned as hot but remains stubbornly entrenched.

entry.title: Liberia, Sierra Leone gain in Ebola crisis; Guinea struggles
entry.summary: FILE - In this Saturday March 7, 2015 file photo, health workers prepare to collect the ashes of people that died of the Ebola virus at a crematorium on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

entry.title: Patient evaluated for Ebola at Colorado hospital after seeing symptoms
entry.summary: Only two people are known to have contracted the virus in the United States - both of them nurses who treated an Ebola patient from Liberia who became sick while visiting Dallas.

entry.title: Patient evaluated for Ebola at Colorado hospital after seeing symptoms
entry.summary: (Reuters) - A patient was being evaluated for Ebola in isolation at a Colorado hospital on Thursday after experiencing symptoms of the disease, health officials said.

entry.title: Sierra Leone to start laying off Ebola workers as cases fall -president
entry.summary: Guinea, which appears to be the worst affected at this time, saw an increase in the number of areas recording Ebola, with seven prefectures reporting at last one confirmed case.

entry.title: Last Cuban Ebola medics leave S.Leone, new clampdown for Easter
entry.summary: A total of 256 Cuban medics had been mobilised in the three countries worst hit by Ebola - Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea.

entry.title: 10 Ebola cases found during Sierra Leone's shutdown
entry.summary: Hundreds of sick people were identified on Friday, Saturday and Sunday as health teams went door-to-door in an operation that also aimed to remind people how to prevent Ebola.

entry.title: Ebola vaccine tests show it could 'neutralise' virus: Geneva hospital
entry.summary:
An experimental Ebola vaccine tested on humans in Europe and Africa sparks the production of the antibodies needed to neutralise the deadly virus, a Geneva hospital said Wednesday.

There is no licensed treatment or vaccine for Ebola, and the World Health Organization last year endorsed rushing potential ones through trials in a bid to stem the epidemic still simmering in west Africa.

entry.title: Merck, NewLink Ebola vaccine appears safe, effective in new studies
5 US aid workers monitored for Ebola in Nebraska released
entry.summary: The Omaha hospital treated three patients with Ebola last fall in its specialized biocontainment unit.

entry.title: 5 US aid workers monitored for Ebola in Nebraska released
entry.summary: (AP) - All five American aid workers being monitored in Nebraska for exposure to Ebola have completed their quarantine periods free from symptoms of the deadly virus.

entry.title: Sierra Leone Ebola lockdown exposes hundreds of suspected cases
Guinea shuts border with Sierra Leone in effort to end Ebola
entry.summary:
Liberia currently has no Ebola patients, and Sierra Leone has seen a fairly steady decline in cases in recent weeks.

Guinea sent security forces to the border on Friday night in response to reports that Sierra Leoneans were streaming over to avoid a three-day, nationwide shutdown over the weekend to help end Ebola.

entry.title: Sierra Leone Ebola lockdown exposes hundreds of suspected cases
entry.summary: Reports to authorities of sick people increased by 191 percent in Western Area, which includes the capital, during the lockdown compared with the previous weekend, said Obi Sesay of the National Ebola Response Center.

entry.title: Guinea shuts border with Sierra Leone in effort to end Ebola
Guinea closes border with Sierra Leone as it ramps up efforts to end Ebola
entry.summary: CONAKRY, Guinea - Guinea has closed its border with Sierra Leone as part of new efforts to stamp out Ebola.

entry.title: 3 West African countries increase fight to end Ebola
entry.summary: In Liberia, the government issued a statement Sunday warning survivors of Ebola to abstain from unprotected sex even beyond the 90-day period earlier recommended.

entry.title: Sierra Leone in new anti-Ebola lockdown
entry.summary: Sierra Leone imposed a three-day nationwide lockdown Friday for the second time in six months in a bid to prevent a resurgence of the deadly Ebola virus.

entry.title: Sierra Leoneans to stay home in final push to stop Ebola
entry.summary: A usually busy street is deserted as Sierra Leone enters a three day country wide lockdown on movement of people due to the Ebola virus in the city of Freetown, Sierra Leone, Friday, March.

entry.title: British Ebola patient cured following experimental treatment
entry.summary:
She was brought back to Britain and successfully treated at the Royal Free in north London, Britain's main centre for Ebola treatment.

The Chinese-made MIL 77 is a close relative of another experimental medicine ZMapp - which British nurse William Pooley received when he was treated at the Royal Free for Ebola last year.

entry.title: British Ebola patient cured after experimental treatment
entry.summary: LONDON (Reuters) - A 25-year-old British military nurse who was the first person in the world to be treated for Ebola with the experimental drug MIL 77 was discharged from hospital on Friday, London's Royal Free Hospital said.

entry.title: Ebola patient thanks hospital staff
Sierra Leoneans to stay home in final push to stop Ebola
entry.summary: Ebola has infected nearly 12,000 people in Sierra Leone, more than in any other country, and it has resorted to some of the most stringent measures to stop the disease.

entry.title: Sierra Leoneans to stay home in final push to stop Ebola
entry.summary: As with a similar operation last year, thousands of teams will fan out around the country, knocking on doors to remind people how Ebola is spread and how to prevent it.

entry.title: Sierra Leoneans to stay home in final push to stop Ebola
entry.summary: Alfred Palo Conteh, the head of Sierra Leone's Ebola response, said a major goal is to fight complacency, more than a year after the outbreak was declared in West Africa.

entry.title: Lockdown bid to stamp out Ebola
entry.summary: Sierra Leone's six million people are being confined to their homes for three days from today as the West African nation resorts again to a sweeping shutdown in a final push to stamp out Ebola.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola improves, in serious condition
Study finds no sign Ebola virus is mutating out of control
entry.summary:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - There is no sign the Ebola virus is mutating in an accelerated way that could make it more virulent or thwart vaccines or drugs under development despite some earlier fears to the contrary, researchers said on Thursday.

The routine genetic changes observed indicate the viral mutations are not likely to affect diagnostic testing or the effectiveness of experimental Ebola vaccines or drugs, the researchers said.

entry.title: U.S. Ebola patient's condition improved to serious: NIH
entry.summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - A U.S. patient being treated for the Ebola virus at a National Institutes of Health facility in Maryland has improved to serious condition from critical, the NIH said on Thursday.

entry.title: New Ebola infections continue to drop but Guinea still a concern
New Ebola infections continue to drop, Guinea still a concern
entry.summary: ABIDJAN (Reuters) - The three nations hardest hit by West Africa's Ebola epidemic recorded the lowest weekly total of new cases so far this year in the week leading up to March 22, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Wednesday.

entry.title: Guinea starts testing Merck vaccine in Ebola hotspots
entry.summary: Guinea started testing an experimental Ebola vaccine from Merck and NewLink Genetics on affected communities this week, in a move officials hope will accelerate the end of an epidemic first detected a year ago.

entry.title: Guinea starts testing Merck vaccine in Ebola hotspots
entry.summary:
But some worry about violent reactions from communities fearful about healthcare workers' intentions in a country where resistance to the anti-Ebola campaign has been strongest.

The Ebola outbreak in West Africa has so far killed more than 10,200 people and, though now waning across the region, case numbers have increased in recent weeks in Guinea.

"Someone arriving with a syringe in their hand might be taken as confirmation of all the rumors going around. It's going to be very complicated," said Jerome Mouton, Guinea country director for leading anti-Ebola charity Medicins Sans Frontieres.

entry.title: Ebola survivor may have infected new Liberia case
entry.summary: Ebola is typically transmitted through contact with the blood, vomit or feces of people who are sick.

entry.title: Official: Ebola survivor may have infected new Liberia case
entry.summary: The woman tested positive for Ebola on Friday, and her case has caused concern because she didn't seem to be linked to any of the people on an Ebola contacts list and said she did not travel to an infected country.

entry.title: Official: Ebola survivor may have infected new Liberia case
entry.summary:
MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) - A Liberian official says a woman who tested positive for Ebola last week is dating a survivor of the disease, offering a possible explanation for how she became the first confirmed case in Liberia after a total absence of cases for more than two weeks.

Dr. Francis Kateh, acting head of Liberia's Ebola Case Management Team, said Tuesday that samples have been taken from the boyfriend for testing.

entry.title: WHO denies politics swayed Ebola emergency declaration
entry.summary: In this photo taken on Friday, Feb. 27, 2015, Health workers carry the remains of a person that they suspect died from the Ebola virus near the village of Gbah on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

entry.title: WHO denies politics swayed Ebola emergency declaration
entry.summary: A June 10 memo sent to WHO Director-General Dr. Margaret Chan says declaring an emergency - or convening a committee to discuss the issue - could be seen as a "hostile act" by Ebola-affected countries.

entry.title: WHO denies politics swayed Ebola emergency declaration
WHO denies politics swayed Ebola emergency declaration
entry.summary: Ebola was judged to have become a health emergency with international implications nearly a month earlier by the U.S. Centers for Disease Prevention and Control.

entry.title: Politics played no role in Ebola emergency declaration: WHO
entry.summary: A year after WHO declared that Ebola had been found in Guinea, the agency is on the defensive over reports that it dragged its feet when raising the international alarm over the disease.

entry.title: Guinea trial begins for suspected killers of Ebola workers
entry.summary: The trial highlights the challenges health workers faced in this Ebola outbreak that has claimed more than 10,000 lives, mostly in the impoverished West African nations of Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia.

entry.title: Guinea trial begins for suspected killers of Ebola workers
Trial begins in Guinea for suspects accused of killing journalists and Ebola workers
entry.summary:
CONAKRY, Guinea - The trial of people accused of killing eight Ebola health workers and journalists opened Monday in a remote region of Guinea.

The killings happened when a delegation of health care workers, including top health officials from the nearby town, visited Womey last September to raise awareness about how to combat Ebola.

entry.title: 1 year after Ebola outbreak declared, Liberians overcome fear to volunteer for vaccine trial
entry.summary:
MONROVIA, Liberia - Liberians are overcoming their fears of Ebola to volunteer for a vaccine trial.

Similarly, in Guinea, authorities started the study by injecting a series of prominent officials, including the head of the country's Ebola response.

entry.title: Liberians overcome fear to volunteer for Ebola vaccine trial
entry.summary:
In Liberia, scientists have fanned out across the country to explain the studies and reduce the fear and confusion that have stymied efforts to contain Ebola.

A community chalkboard at a busy intersection in Monrovia recently read: "Ebola vaccines 1 vs. Public fear 4."

entry.title: Liberians overcome fear to volunteer for Ebola vaccine trial
entry.summary: That will require getting a high-level of participation; about 60 percent compliance is hoped for, said Dr. Marie-Paule Kieny, who leads Ebola vaccine research at the World Health Organization.

entry.title: Liberia investigates how latest Ebola patient got infected
Liberia officials: New patient tests positive for Ebola
entry.summary: Tolbert Nyenswah, who runs Liberia's Ebola response, also said he had been told the test result was positive.

entry.title: Liberia officials: New patient tests positive for Ebola
entry.summary:
MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) " A patient has tested positive for Ebola in Liberia's capital, officials said Friday, deflating hopes that the West African nation had beaten the disease after weeks with no new cases.

Now, a new patient has tested positive, said Dr. Francis Kateh, the acting head of the country's Ebola Incident Management Team.

entry.title: Liberian official: Patient tests positive for Ebola, over 2 weeks after last case discharged
Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary:
In a meeting at WHO headquarters on July 30, 2014 about Ebola, Liu said she told WHO Director-General Dr. Margaret Chan, "You have the legitimacy and the authority to label it an emergency...You need to step up to the plate."

12, 2014 file photo, a child covers his face as he looks at a man suspected of suffering from the Ebola virus, in a main street and busy area of Monrovia, Liberia.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary: Britain, China, the U.S. and others all built Ebola clinics in West Africa, but many weren't ready until late fall - after the epidemic's peak.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary: It was around that time that West Africa's Ebola epidemic surpassed the previous largest outbreak, in Uganda, where it infected 425 people in 2000 and killed about half.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary:
GENEVA (AP) - By early June of last year, the Ebola epidemic in West Africa was the deadliest ever recorded.

"I told her, 'Dr. Chan, the Ebola epidemic in West Africa is out of control,'" Liu recalled telling Chan in a July 30 meeting in Geneva.

WHO's Ebola response leader, Dr. Bruce Aylward, couldn't say whether an earlier declaration would have made a difference, noting that "the overall response slowed down" after the emergency was declared.

entry.title: Sierra Leone to lock down Ebola hotspots next week
5 key findings from AP's story on WHO and the Ebola outbreak
Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency
entry.summary: In mid-April, an experienced Ebola expert with WHO's Africa office wrote to Geneva, with disturbing news that many staffers at a leading hospital in Guinea had been exposed to the virus.

entry.title: A delayed emergency and challenges for reform: 5 key findings from AP's story on WHO and Ebola
entry.summary: An Ebola-infected WHO consultant in Sierra Leone violated WHO health protocols, creating a rift with Doctors Without Borders that was only resolved when WHO was thrown out of a shared hotel.

entry.title: 5 key findings from AP's story on WHO and the Ebola outbreak
entry.summary: Internal emails and documents suggest the U.N. health agency was afraid of provoking conflict with the Ebola-stricken countries and wary that a declaration could interfere with the economy and the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca.

entry.title: Emails show UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency on economic, political grounds
Healthcare worker in Nebraska tests negative for Ebola
entry.summary:
CHICAGO (Reuters) - A U.S. healthcare worker who was admitted to the biocontainment unit at Nebraska Medicine on Sunday has been released after testing negative for Ebola, the hospital said on Thursday.

All had contact with an infected co-worker in Sierra Leone who is being treated for Ebola at the National Institutes of Health biocontainment facility in Maryland.

entry.title: Ebola: Sierra Leone plans second lockdown to stem epidemic
entry.summary: Authorities hope the lockdown will set the country back on course to meet a mid-April deadline for eradicating Ebola, as announced by the leaders of Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone in February.

entry.title: Ebola-hit Sierra Leone to lock down 2.5 million people
entry.summary: Sierra Leone said Thursday it will confine around 2.5 million people to their homes across the capital and in the north in a three-day shutdown aimed at stemming the Ebola epidemic.

entry.title: Liberia: Families of health workers killed by Ebola get $5k
entry.summary: So far, 11 families have received $5,000 each, said Tolbert Nyenswah, who leads the government's Ebola response; dozens more payments are in the works.

entry.title: Liberia begins making $5,000 payments to families of health workers who died of Ebola
entry.summary:
MONROVIA, Liberia - Liberia's government has begun making payments to the families of health workers who died of Ebola in the world's worst ever outbreak, an official said Thursday.

Ebola, often called the caregivers' disease, has decimated the ranks of doctors and nurses in the three countries hardest hit in this outbreak: Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: Guinea says number of Ebola patients more than doubles since Feb
entry.summary: Dr Rafiou Diallo, a spokesman for Guinea's health ministry, said there were 91 suspected and confirmed Ebola patients in treatment centres compared with just 39 in February.

entry.title: Two more U.S. healthcare workers repatriated for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: Neither of the two healthcare workers brought back Wednesday has tested positive for Ebola, but they are being monitored because they might have been exposed to a colleague who has contracted it.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another three-day, countrywide shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary: The shutdown is expected to take place March 27 through 29, according to Patrick Fatoma, another official with the Ebola response center.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary: Sierra Leone is "hoping it will be the last push to end Ebola outbreak. We want it to be community-owned and for people to do the proper things," said Fatoma.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary: In the drive to zero cases in Sierra Leone, the government will again ask residents to stay in their homes for three days, Alfred Palo Conteh, head of the country's National Ebola Response Center, said Wednesday.

entry.title: Sierra Leone plans another shutdown to stop Ebola's spread
entry.summary: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone (AP) - Sierra Leone is planning another three-day, countrywide shutdown March 27 through 29 to ferret out Ebola cases, remind people how to protect themselves from the disease and control its transmission.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: On Tuesday, March 17, 2015, health officials said four more medical aid workers have been flown from West Africa to the United States, for monitoring for Ebola.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: Since last summer, several U.S. aid workers have gotten Ebola and have been flown back to the U.S. for care.

entry.title: 4 more aid workers flown back to US for Ebola monitoring
U.S. Ebola patient now in critical condition: NIH
American who contracted Ebola now in critical condition
entry.summary: One of those being monitored in Nebraska has developed symptoms of Ebola and was being moved to an isolation unit, hospital officials said in a news release Monday.

entry.title: Four Americans arrive in Nebraska for Ebola monitoring
10 US charity staff to leave Sierra Leone amid Ebola scare
entry.summary:
Ten clinicians with a Boston-based nonprofit organization responding to the Ebola outbreak in Sierra Leone are to be transported to the United States after one of their colleagues was infected with the deadly disease.

Partners in Health said in a statement Saturday that the 10, the largest group to be evacuated to the United States over possible Ebola exposure, would travel on non-commercial aircraft and be isolated in Ebola treatment facilities.

On March 11, a Partners in Health medical worker in Sierra Leone tested positive for Ebola, and the 10 fellow workers "came to the aid of their ailing colleague," the organization's statement said.

entry.title: 10 US charity staff to leave Sierra Leone amid Ebola scare
10 US charity staff to leave Sierra Leone amid Ebola scare
entry.summary:
The 10 have not shown signs of Ebola and Partners in Health said the evacuations were ordered "out of an abundance of caution."

Both countries are still reporting dozens of new cases every week and the number of Ebola deaths taking place outside of hospitals remains high, suggesting that people are wary of seeking help or are hiding cases.

In both countries there are still regular attacks against Western aid workers and officials are unable to track where the Ebola virus is spreading.

entry.title: Americans returning from Africa for Ebola monitoring
entry.summary: ATLANTA (AP) - Public health officials said Saturday that a number of Americans will return from west Africa to be monitored after possibly being exposed to Ebola.

entry.title: Ebola: at least 10 US citizens possibly exposed to be flown back from Africa
entry.summary: A US healthcare worker who tested positive for Ebola while in Sierra Leone arrived at the NIH on Friday and was in serious condition, the NIH said.

entry.title: At least 10 Americans being flown to U.S. after possible Ebola exposure
entry.summary:
At least 10 Americans possibly exposed to the deadly Ebola virus were being flown to the United States from Sierra Leone for observation, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Saturday.

CDC spokesman Thomas Skinner said 10 people who may have been exposed to the unidentified Ebola patient or who had a similar exposure to the virus as the patient were being flown to the United States.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola arrives at Maryland hospital
entry.summary: That person has shown no symptoms, is not diagnosed with Ebola and is expected to "voluntarily self-isolate" for a 21-day incubation period.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola arrives at Maryland hospital
entry.summary: (AP) - An American healthcare worker who contracted Ebola while volunteering in a Sierra Leone treatment unit arrived safely at the National Institutes of Health's hospital in Maryland, officials said Friday.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola arrives at US hospital
entry.summary: The patient is the 11th person with Ebola to be treated in the U.S. and the second admitted to the NIH Clinical Center.

entry.title: American who contracted Ebola in Africa arrives at hospital in Maryland for treatment
News24.com | American with Ebola to be treated in US
entry.summary: Bethesda - An American health worker who contracted Ebola while volunteering in Africa will be admitted to a hospital at the National Institutes of Health, the agency announced on Thursday.

entry.title: Last Ebola patient is released in Liberia
entry.summary: Yardolo's release brings Liberia hope after about a year of battling the deadly Ebola virus, which killed more than 4,100 people in this West African country.

entry.title: Ebola expert volunteers to trial potential life-saving drug
entry.summary: The assistant director general, Marie-Paule Kieny, who leads Ebola research and development at the WHO, said: "The Ebola epidemic shows signs of receding but we cannot let down our guard until we reach zero cases.

entry.title: Last Ebola patient is released in Liberia
entry.summary:
MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) - Liberia released its last Ebola patient, a 58-year old teacher, from a treatment center on Thursday, beginning its countdown to being declared Ebola free.

Yardolo said she had been admitted to the Chinese-run Ebola treatment center in the Paynesville district of Monrovia on Feb. 18.

The St. Paul's Bridge community where she resides and works had become the last "hotspot" for Ebola cases in Monrovia, according to Tolbert Nyenswah, Assistant Health Minister and head of the country's Ebola response.

entry.title: Last Ebola patient is released in Liberia
entry.summary:
There are no other confirmed cases of Ebola in the country, and as such Liberia can begin to count up to 42 days to be declared Ebola free in keeping with World Health Organization protocols and standards, Nyenswah said Wednesday.

Liberian President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has said no country can be declared Ebola free until all the other countries have no cases.

entry.title: WHO to begin large-scale testing of Ebola vaccine in Guinea
entry.summary:
The World Health Organization says it will soon start large-scale testing of an experimental Ebola vaccine in Guinea to see how effective it might be in preventing future outbreaks of the dreaded virus.

The West African nations of Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been hardest hit in the yearlong Ebola outbreak, which is estimated to have left more than 9,800 people dead.

In a statement Thursday, the U.N. health agency said the vaccine study will focus on Basse Guinee, the region that has Guinea's most Ebola cases.

entry.title: WHO to begin large-scale testing of Ebola vaccine in Guinea
entry.summary:
The agency said the spread of Ebola remains "widespread" in Sierra Leone and noted that cases have jumped both there and in Guinea.

Officials also said the number of Ebola deaths taking place outside of hospitals still remains high in Guinea and Sierra Leone, "suggesting that the need for early isolation and treatment is not yet understood, accepted or acted upon."

entry.title: After Ebola ban, N. Korea opens marathon to foreigners
entry.summary: TOKYO (AP) - After lifting travel restrictions it imposed because of concerns over the Ebola virus, North Korea says foreigners can now take part in one of its most popular tourist events - the annual Pyongyang marathon, a travel agency said Thursday.

entry.title: After Ebola ban, N. Korea opens marathon to foreigners
entry.summary: Even though no cases of Ebola had been reported anywhere near North Korea, the country shut out foreign tourists in October with some of the strictest Ebola regulations in the world, including saying that only local runners would be allowed into the marathon in April.

entry.title: Ohio bridal shop linked to Ebola survivor will sell building
entry.summary: Dallas nurse Amber Vinson visited Coming Attractions Bridal & Formal in Akron days before she was diagnosed with Ebola last fall.

entry.title: Ohio bridal shop linked to Ebola survivor will sell building
entry.summary: AKRON, Ohio (AP) - A northeast Ohio bridal shop that was linked to an Ebola survivor and later announced plans to close has put its building up for sale.

entry.title: Liberia calls for Ebola 'Marshall Plan' to rebuild economies
entry.summary: Sirleaf told fellow regional leaders and delegates at an international conference on Ebola in Brussels that restoring economic growth in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone is a long-term and costly task.

entry.title: Liberia calls for Ebola 'Marshall Plan' to rebuild economies
entry.summary: BRUSSELS (AP) - Liberia's president on Tuesday called for an Ebola "Marshall Plan" to help rebuild economies in West African nations devastated by the virus.

entry.title: Report: As Ebola wanes, other countries remain vulnerable
entry.summary:
Some of the travelers checked by workers with surgical masks had traveled through a West African country affected by Ebola, or sat next to passengers who did, and Chadian authorities weren't taking any chances.

After causing nearly 10,000 recorded deaths, the Ebola epidemic is waning in the three worst-hit countries, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.

It found that 28 countries were worse off than Liberia, which has seen the most deaths from the Ebola epidemic that began in December 2013.

entry.title: Report: As Ebola wanes, other countries remain vulnerable
North Korea lifts Ebola travel restrictions
entry.summary:
Officials in Pyongyang said the restrictions and quarantines would continue for visitors from Ebola-affected countries in Africa and those countries that have borders with them.

North Korean media had suggested the Ebola virus was created by the U.S. military for use as a biological weapon.

entry.title: North Korea lifts Ebola travel restrictions
entry.summary:
TOKYO (AP) - North Korea has lifted severe restrictions on foreign travel it imposed last year to keep the Ebola virus from crossing its borders.

"We have been informed by Air Koryo that North Korea's borders are now open for travel and the four-month long Ebola travel ban was lifted as of Monday," Uri Tours said.

entry.title: Ebola survivor leaves US after recovery to return to Africa
entry.summary: Nancy Writebol last summer became the second American infected with the Ebola virus while working at a hospital SIM supports in the Liberian capital of Monrovia.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary: On the first day Pham treated Duncan, when Ebola was suspected but not yet diagnosed, she wore a regular isolation gown, double gloves, a surgical mask with a plastic shield and double booties.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary: Duncan, who contracted Ebola in his native Liberia but started showing symptoms during a trip to the U.S., died at the hospital.

entry.title: UN warns against complacency as Ebola fight enters new phase
entry.summary:
But U.N. Special Envoy on Ebola David Nabarro said the fight has reached a "second phase, getting to zero, and it really is the hardest part."

"It's a really difficult, painstaking task," he said in Brussels, on the eve of a major international conference on Ebola expected to draw around 600 delegates, including the leaders of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: UN warns against complacency as Ebola fight enters new phase
entry.summary: BRUSSELS (AP) - The United Nations is urging donors, organizations and countries fighting Ebola in West Africa not to give in to complacency as the death toll from the virus climbs toward 10,000.

entry.title: Nurse who was first person infected with Ebola in U.S. sues Dallas hospital
entry.summary: Pham became a national symbol of hope in fighting Ebola after she made a recovery and was greeted in the Oval Office by President Barack Obama.

entry.title: Ebola survivor sues Dallas hospital over infection
entry.summary:
DALLAS - The first person infected with Ebola in the United States, nurse Nina Pham, sued a Texas hospital on Monday, saying it did not do enough to prevent her from contracting the deadly virus and invaded her privacy after she was diagnosed with it.

The suit claims that the THR's Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital did not initially provide adequate protective gear for medical staff or instructions on how to treat someone with Ebola.

entry.title: Ebola survivor sues Dallas hospital over infection
entry.summary: "I was hoping that THR would be more open and honest about everything that happened at the hospital, and the things they didn't do that led to me getting infected with Ebola. But that didn't happen and I felt I was left with no choice but to turn to the courts for help," Pham said in a statement.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary: Pham says in her lawsuit that the hospital was unprepared to treat Ebola cases and that she was an unwitting pawn in its public relations campaign to restore its reputation.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary: She contracted Ebola last fall while caring for Thomas Eric Duncan at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas.

entry.title: ?Used as a PR pawn?: Nurse who survived Ebola infection says Texas hospital failed her
entry.summary:
DALLAS - A 26-year-old nurse said in a newspaper interview that a hospital where she had worked in Dallas and its parent company failed her when she contracted Ebola while caring for the first person in the U.S. diagnosed with the deadly disease.

Pham and another nurse who worked at Texas Health Presbyterian, Amber Vinson, both became infected with Ebola after caring for Duncan, according to medical records released to The Associated Press.

entry.title: Nurse Treated For Ebola To Sue Texas Hospital
Sierra Leone's VP in self-quarantine after guard dies from Ebola
entry.summary: Sierra Leone's vice-president has put himself in quarantine following the death from Ebola of one of his security guards.

entry.title: Sierra Leone's Samuel Sam-Sumana in quarantine over Ebola worries
entry.summary:
Despite his quarantine, Sam-Sumana is set to become acting president later Sunday when President Ernest Bai Koroma leaves Sierra Leone to attend a EU conference on Ebola in Belgium.

Sam-Sumana's dramatic quarantine comes as Sierra Leone is experiencing a rise in new Ebola cases which prompted President Ernest Bai Koroma to reinstate restrictions on Saturday.

entry.title: Liberia lifts Ebola curfew and re-opens borders
WHO official concerned as decline in Ebola cases levels off
entry.summary: The steep decline in Ebola case numbers has levelled off over the past month and the development is a cause for concern, the official leading the World Health Organization's response to the outbreak said Friday.

entry.title: Liberia to end Ebola curfew, open land border crossings
entry.summary: Once the center of the worst Ebola outbreak in history, Liberia has recorded more than 9,000 confirmed, suspected and probable cases and 3,900 deaths.

entry.title: Liberia to end Ebola curfew, open land border crossings
entry.summary:
MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) - Liberia's president on Friday ordered officials to lift an overnight curfew put in place six months ago to fight the Ebola epidemic and to reopen the country's land border crossings.

In a statement, the White House said President Barack Obama and Sirleaf would discuss the current Ebola response and the region's economic recovery plans during their Feb. 27 meeting.

entry.title: World Health Organization approves 1st quick test for Ebola
World Health Organization approves 1st quick test for Ebola
entry.summary: Almost 24,000 people have been infected and nearly 9,400 people have died from the current Ebola outbreak, which began in West Africa over a year ago.

entry.title: Health24.com | Breakthrough 15-minute Ebola test gets the nod
entry.summary: It is able to correctly identify about 92 percent of Ebola infected patients and 85 percent of those not infected with the virus, the WHO said.

entry.title: WHO approves breakthrough 15-minute Ebola test
entry.summary:
Geneva: The World Health Organization has approved the first rapid test for Ebola in a potential breakthrough for ending an epidemic that has killed almost 10,000 people in West Africa, it said on Friday.

The health charity Medecins Sans Frontieres, which has been at the forefront of the fight against Ebola, had expressed an interest, he said.

"The big fear has been that the market gets flooded with tests of unknown quality, or unknown performance, and with Ebola you need to know what are the limitations. A false positive has enormous implications. So does a false positive," she said.

entry.title: WHO approves 15-minute Ebola test
Fifteen-minute Ebola test approved
entry.summary: The first rapid blood test for Ebola has been approved for use by the World Health Organization.

entry.title: Liberia leader to visit US, 1st visit since Ebola outbreak
entry.summary:
WASHINGTON (AP) - The president of Liberia will visit the United States later this month, her first trip to the country since the Ebola outbreak in West Africa.

Since an Ebola outbreak began in December 2013 in the West African country of Guinea, there have been about 7,900 deaths, mostly in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: Liberia reopens schools as Ebola wanes
entry.summary: A student has her body temperature checked as part of an Ebola screening at Don Bosco High School, as schools reopen in the Liberian capital, Monrovia.

entry.title: Liberia reopens schools as Ebola wanes
entry.summary:
Monrovia: Thousands of Liberian children in pristine uniforms flocked back to school for the first time in six months, after a after a closure designed to stem the spread of the worst Ebola outbreak in history.

"Authorities in the three countries are looking at catchup sessions and cancelling some school vacations. It will be challenging," said Sayo Aoki, education specialist in Ebola Emergencies at the UN Children's Fund.

entry.title: Liberia reopens schools as Ebola wanes
Sierra Leone promises probe into Ebola spending
entry.summary: As Ebola is being brought under control, Sierra Leone plans to re-open its schools at the end of March.

entry.title: Sierra Leone promises probe into Ebola spending
entry.summary:
The report by Sierra Leone's Auditor General covered the months of May through October 2014, and looked at donations received directly by the government to fight Ebola.

More than 3,300 people have died from Ebola with nearly 11,000 cases over the past year in Sierra Leone, where transmission remains the highest in the world.

entry.title: Sierra Leone promises probe into Ebola spending
entry.summary: Neighboring Liberia reported just five confirmed Ebola cases last week and it reopened most of its schools Monday.

entry.title: Liberia schools reopen after 6-month Ebola closure
entry.summary:
"I am very happy to be counted among the living and I pray that Ebola be eradicated from this country."

Liberia has seen the highest death toll from the Ebola epidemic, with 3,800 killed.

In Sierra Leone on Monday, the government promised a full investigation after an internal audit found that nearly one-third of the money it received to fight Ebola was used without saving the necessary receipts and invoices to justify the spending.

entry.title: Liberia schools reopen after 6-month Ebola closure
entry.summary:
MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) - Students in Liberia began returning to the classroom Monday after a six-month closure during the Ebola epidemic that left thousands dead, lining up in their uniforms to have their temperatures taken before they could enter school gates.

A few, though, remained a bit fearful about returning even though there are just a handful of Ebola cases left in the country that once saw 100 new patients a week.

Nearly 9,200 people have died since the first Ebola deaths in rural Guinea in December 2013.
